stem: An 89-year-old client from a long-term care facility is admitted for 'not acting like himself.' He is confused and cool to the touch. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client is an 89-year-old male admitted at 14:00 from a long-term care facility for acute altered mental status. He is generally confused and less responsive than baseline.
Background: The client has a history of stroke and an indwelling urinary catheter due to a neurogenic bladder. He has been residing at the facility for the past 3 years.
Assessment: The client is stuporous and cool to the touch. Vital signs: BP 88/52 mmHg, HR 108 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 95.8°F (35.4°C), SpO2 91%. Urine in the catheter bag is cloudy and has a strong odor. Lactate is 3.9 mmol/L. WBC is 4,200/µL. The patient is CAM+ for delirium.
Recommendation: The provider should evaluate the client for possible septic shock and initiate appropriate interventions, including blood cultures and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/52 mmHg, HR 108 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 95.8°F (35.4°C), SpO2 91%.

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV warm fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics as prescribed.
Obtain blood and urine cultures immediately (before antibiotics).
Administer PO ibuprofen to treat the underlying inflammation.
Place the client in Trendelenburg position to improve BP.

parameterOptions.text: Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) and level of consciousness
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The client is most likely experiencing Geriatric Septic Shock (c2). Elderly patients often present with atypical signs of infection, including acute confusion (delirium), hypothermia (temperature below 96.8°F or 36°C), and hypotension. The elevated lactate level (3.9 mmol/L) further supports the diagnosis of shock. The presence of cloudy, malodorous urine in a patient with an indwelling catheter is highly suggestive of a urinary source of infection. Priority nursing actions include obtaining blood and urine cultures immediately (a2) to identify the causative organism before initiating broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV fluids as prescribed (a1). Monitoring should include Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) and level of consciousness (p1) to assess perfusion and neurological status, as well as urine output and lung sounds (p2) to monitor fluid balance and prevent fluid overload during resuscitation.
clinicalPearls: Hypothermia (< 96.8°F) in a septic patient can be a more concerning sign than fever, indicating a severely compromised thermoregulatory system.
Cloudy/malodorous urine in an elderly patient with acute confusion should raise strong suspicion for urosepsis, especially in the presence of an indwelling catheter.
The 'cold' presentation in elderly patients with sepsis can be attributed to an aging hypothalamus and blunted immune response, making early recognition challenging.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the patient does not have an infection because the WBC count (4,200/µL) is within normal limits.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In elderly patients with sepsis, the WBC count may remain within normal limits or even decrease (leukopenia). Rely on other indicators such as MAP, lactate, mental status changes, and temperature instability to assess for sepsis.

mnemonic.title: COLD Sepsis
mnemonic.expansion: C-Confusion (acute change in mental status), O-Out of range (Cold) Temperature (hypothermia), L-Low Blood Pressure (hypotension), D-Delirium (acute).
